Award.AwardTitle: Robust Least Squares Discretization for Mixed Variational Formulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to enable more reliable, fast, and accurate simulation methods for a variety of applications in science and engineering, such as electromagnetism, elasticity and acoustics, fluid flow, and diffusion through heterogenous porous media. The project focuses on efficient computational methods based on finite element analysis. Specific applications include modeling compressible gas dynamics and computational fluid mechanics for atmospheric prediction and ocean fluid flow behavior, as well as computational solution of the time-harmonic Maxwell model with applications in nano-optics and analog signal packages. This project will provide interdisciplinary applied mathematics training and research experiences for students.

The project will develop, analyze, and implement robust and efficient numerical algorithms for solving partial differential equations (PDEs) that admit variational formulations with different types of test and trial spaces. When approximating the solutions of these PDEs, it is desirable to obtain robust estimates of all physical quantities in the presence of parameters, such as diffusion coefficient or frequency. It is also important to obtain good approximations of the solution, even in the case of low regularity near boundaries or along material discontinuities, or in the case of low data regularity. The focus of the project is on approximating PDE models with parameters and discontinuous coefficients. The project develops a general discretization and algorithm development method that bridges between the field of symmetric saddle point problems and the field of preconditioning elliptic symmetric problems. The project aims to: introduce a new saddle point least-squares theory that allows non-conforming trial spaces to approximate discontinuous solutions of PDEs; construct locally smooth projection type of trial spaces that lead to higher order of approximation for the solution or related quantities of interest; introduce optimal test spaces and balanced norms that allow robust approximation for parametric problems; and construct efficient preconditioning techniques for general mixed variational formulations. The research will broaden the mathematical theory and the range of applications of the mixed finite-element approximation field and will create new connections among mixed variational formulations, adaptive and multilevel techniques, and preconditioning parametric or fractional norms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our  research contributed to theoretical  and practical aspect of a building  general framework for finite element discretization of mixed variational formulations.  It  established   new connections between  general finite element theory,  multilevel  norm representation and preconditioning, saddle point  theory, least squares methods, and multilevel iterative methods. Applications of the work done under DMS-2011615 include  building algorithms for modeling convection dominated flows,  elasticity and acoustics,   diffusion through heterogenous porous media, and heat transfer. 
The project provided a unified theoretical and computational framework that allows  robust estimates of physical quantities  even in the presence of low regularity solutions, discontinuities in material coefficients, or low regularity data.  We  obtained accurate approximation of  the physical quantities of interest,  by combining  powerful mathematical analysis with algorithm design, and sustained  testing of the proposed algorithms. 
The breakthrough achievements of the project  rely on a new  saddle point least squares reformulation of variational problems, adoption of optimal test spaces,  designing new  trial  and test spaces that include non-conforming or locally conforming  spaces, the inclusion of  a priori and a posteriori efficient residual estimates, the use of  parameter dependent  norms,  and the adoption of efficient preconditioning techniques such as multilevel and multigrid algorithms.
Our work  will help replace  experimental  simulation and data collection with  computer testing and computer simulation of Partial Differential Equation (PDE)  models. We designed  fast and robust algorithms for speeding up  computational fluid dynamics models. Our analysis and  numerical approach for the  convection dominated  problems  has applications in solving complicated fluid flow models and heat transfer problems. The  proposed algorithms for solving the  reaction diffusion problem  has applications in  heat transfer problems in thin domains or in  improving the computational  time for  approximating  parabolic reaction diffusion  problems used for  heat transfer models.
The project results  contributed to the training  of researchers  in the theoretical and the computational aspects of the finite element discretization of various variational formulation of PDEs. The  PI's students  developed  new theoretical and numerical analysis abilities  for the finite element discretization. The research  led to programming  skills  and software  development that can be used in the general context of finite element discretization. 
The PI has advised and trained two graduate student  on mathematical and computational aspects directly related with the  DMS-2011615 project. One Ph.D. thesis that is grant related, {\it Saddle  Point Least Square and Petrov-Galerkin Methods Applied to Reaction-Diffusion and  Convection-Diffusion Equations}, was completed in June 2023  by one of PI's students and another Ph.D. thesis is expected to be defended by the end of  2026. In addition, three undergraduate students worked on the projects under the GEMS summer research program at the  University of Delaware. The project also led to development of programming  skills and analysis abilities for my students that took  numerical analysis and introduction to discretization  classes taught at University of Delaware.  Since Fall 2020, the PI and his collaborators gave more than 25 presentations, that are  DMS-2011615 grant related, at local and non-local professional meetings.
Graduate and undergraduate  students  benefited  from the DMS-2011615 project  due to various  presentations in seminars and symposia at the University of Delaware and other institutions. Specific topics from DMS-2011615  research are  included in the   curriculum for graduate courses. During Spring 2020-Fall 2024, the PI also taught eight  numerical discretization classes at University of Delaware, addressing  ideas and concepts from the DMS- 2011615 project.
